{"step_by_step_thinking": "Extracellular vesicles are small, membrane-bound particles that are released by cells into the extracellular environment. They are known to be produced by a variety of cell types, including bacteria. These vesicles can carry various cellular components, such as proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids, and can play roles in cell-to-cell communication, pathogenesis, and other processes.", "answer_choice": "A"}
